{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3543722,"name":"kuzey","username":"kuzeyatay","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/59ef9b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-28T19:23:58.650Z","cooked":"

Hi, our elevator has a wrist mechanism connected to the elevator and when it bumps into something we loose position. we use the krakens internal encoder for motion magic and can use a rev trough bore absolute encoder that is laying around. how can we make it so that the wrist doesn’t loose its position when its hit? and also can i detect the drift in my code?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-02-28T19:23:58.650Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":93,"readers_count":92,"score":28.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":493657,"topic_slug":"wrist-loosing-position-after-collision","display_username":"kuzey","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61536,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wrist-loosing-position-after-collision/493657/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3543724,"name":"K","username":"Kr_117","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/6de8d8/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-28T19:30:41.347Z","cooked":"

I believe if you code in set positions the motors will go back to the same positions.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-02-28T19:30:41.347Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":37.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":493657,"topic_slug":"wrist-loosing-position-after-collision","display_username":"K","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73657,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2024"},"post_url":"/t/wrist-loosing-position-after-collision/493657/2","custom_user_title":"2024","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3543727,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-28T19:34:36.934Z","cooked":"

CTRE has something like this baked into their phoenix6 API where you can use a CANcoder (their absolute encoder) right with the TalonFX on a Kraken. I know that doesn’t help you, but wanted to point it out because, yes, this is a good idea. And you can probably yank ideas from other implementations.

But basically somewhere in your robot loop you’d check to see if the absolute encoder is reading different enough from the motor encoder to warrant writing the position back to the motor.

Is it mechanically skipping when hit?

I think moving the rev through bore encoder to be on the mechanism itself so it records the true position of the mechanism and can’t skip would be the best solution. There’s no easy way I know of to detect when a belt has skipped purely through software.

i also thinked that way but the whole system is dead axle so i cant directly mount it on the mechanism

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-02-28T19:59:27.632Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":42,"readers_count":41,"score":8.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":493657,"topic_slug":"wrist-loosing-position-after-collision","display_username":"kuzey","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51219,"username":"dh28567","name":"Devin Hazelton","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dh28567/{size}/172970_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61536,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wrist-loosing-position-after-collision/493657/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3543748,"name":"Val","username":"Otter502","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/otter502/{size}/245799_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-28T19:59:33.740Z","cooked":"

There are two main methods we use when we can’t make mechanical changes to the robot
A. use an absolute encoder to read the position of the mechanism
B. have a hardstop which you record the position of and let the drivers run the mechanism manually and have a button which “sets” the encoder’s position to the known position
I hope this helps!
